key_points: Both Democrats and Republicans have supported stimulus bills that sent checks to prisoners in the past.
Democrats opposed a Republican amendment to bar prisoners from receiving $1,400 stimulus checks, arguing it would hurt prisoners' families.
Senators Tom Cotton and Bill Cassidy proposed an amendment to prevent stimulus checks going to prisoners, which failed on a party-line vote.
Cotton criticized the decision, noting prisoners haven't lost jobs due to the pandemic and thus shouldn't need stimulus money.
Dick Durbin countered that blocking stimulus checks to prisoners would disproportionately harm children and communities of color.
Eligibility for stimulus payments is broad, requiring citizenship or legal residency and either a tax return filing or completion of an IRS form.
Previous stimulus checks during the Trump administration were also available to prisoners.
Cotton's press secretary claimed the issue with prisoners receiving checks in the CARES Act was 'unanticipated' and couldn't be amended in December's bill.
Republicans had opportunities to address the issue of stimulus payments to prisoners in past legislation but did not.
The claim that Democrats voted to give stimulus checks to prisoners is rated as 'Mostly True', acknowledging that Republicans also supported such measures in the past.
spokespersons: James Arnold (Press Secretary for Tom Cotton)
